title: 107_hr1833
content: The Gas Tax Fairness Act of 2001 may be cited as the "Gas Tax Fairness Act." It includes a six-month suspension of fuel taxes. The Gas Tax Fairness Act of 2001, also known as the "Gas Tax Fairness Act," includes a temporary suspension of fuel taxes for six months. This suspension reduces the rates of tax on gasoline, diesel fuel, kerosene, aviation fuel, and fuel used on inland waterways to zero. The Gas Tax Fairness Act of 2001 includes a temporary suspension of fuel taxes for six months, reducing tax rates on various fuels to zero. The amendment mentioned in the text will be effective upon the enactment of the Act. SEC. 3. FLOOR STOCK REFUNDS. Under this provision, if tax has been imposed on liquid before the tax suspension date and the liquid is held by a dealer for sale without being used, the taxpayer can claim a credit or refund for the excess tax paid. Claims must be filed within 6 months of the tax suspension date with the Secretary of the Treasury. The provision allows taxpayers to claim a credit or refund for excess tax paid on liquid held by a dealer before the tax suspension date. Claims must be filed within 6 months of the tax suspension date. No credit or refund is allowed for liquid held in retail stocks intended for retail sale. Definitions for "dealer" and "held by a dealer" are provided. The terms "dealer" and "held by a dealer" are defined as per section 6412 of the Internal Revenue Code. The term "tax suspension date" refers to the start of the suspension period under section 4081(f) of the Code. Rules similar to those in section 6412 apply to this provision. SEC. 4. FLOOR STOCKS TAX. Imposition of Tax: A floor stocks tax is imposed on taxable liquid held on the floor stocks tax date, calculated as the excess of the tax that would be imposed if the taxable event occurred on that date over the tax already paid. Liability and Payment: The person holding the liquid is liable for the tax, to be paid as prescribed by the Secretary within 6 months of the floor stocks tax date. The floor stocks tax date defines the day after the suspension period, and it applies to taxable liquids like gasoline, diesel fuel, and aviation fuel. The term "date" refers to the day after the suspension period under section 4081(f) of the Code. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Treasury or their delegate. The tax imposed by subsection (a) does not apply to taxable liquid held for exempt uses or in the tank of a motor vehicle or motorboat. No tax is imposed on gasoline held on the floor stocks tax date. The exemption applies to gasoline up to 4,000 gallons and diesel fuel, kerosene, or aviation fuel up to 2,000 gallons held by a person. Submission of required information to the Secretary is necessary. Fuel exempt from tax under subsection (d) or (e) is not considered. The term "controlled group" under subsection (d) or (e) means all persons treated as 1 person, with regulations prescribed by the Secretary for nonincorporated persons under common control. Principles similar to those in subparagraph (A) apply to a group of persons under common control, even if not all are corporations. Other laws, including penalties, applicable to certain fuel taxes also apply to floor stock taxes imposed in the same manner as if imposed under specific sections of the tax code. SEC. 5. PROTECTION OF HIGHWAY TRUST FUND. The amounts transferred to the Highway Trust Fund under section 9503 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 shall be determined as if this Act had not been acted.
